Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sat in the ambulance, engine idling, eyes flicking between the dispatch radio and the clock. As an ambulance driver, I’m always ready—every second counts when a call comes in. The expectation is clear: drop everything, speed to the scene, save lives. But as a citizen, I have other duties. My tax documents are stacked neatly at home, waiting for me to double-check them before filing. The community center is hosting a free vaccine clinic this weekend, and I promised my neighbor I’d help organize the line and hand out forms. I want to do my part, to be the kind of person who shows up for my community, not just in emergencies but in everyday ways too. Yet, I can’t ignore the possibility that the radio will crackle to life at any moment, pulling me away. The weight of both roles presses on me—one demanding my constant readiness, the other asking for my steady, civic presence. I stare out the window, heart tugged in two directions, wondering how I can possibly be in both places when the time comes.
